text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen now if 
you're a fan of Thai food many of you probably

have had a dish called som tum or green papaya 
salad super popular I have a video for it but did

you know that in Thailand we make som tum with 
so many other non papaya ingredients and so if

you live in a place where green papaya is hard 
to find or super expensive this is the episode

for you I'm going to show you a variation that I 
very much love it's perfect for the summer it's

beautiful and refreshing it is what we call tum 
tang kao poad tum means to pound it's a prefix

for all papaya salad type dishes tang is short 
for tangwa or cucumber and kao poad it is sweet corn

so it's a salad of corn and cucumber so let's 
get started so the first thing we're going to

talk about is of course our star or a corn I've 
got here one ear of corn have no idea why it's

called ear of corn but basically all you have to 
do is cook this bring a big pot of water to a full

boil and boil the corn for 6 minutes ok when the 
corn comes out give it a little sprinkle of salt

and let it cool completely and this is what you 
get now so what you're gonna do is just gonna

slice off the kernels and try your best to keep 
it in big-ish pieces because when you go to toss

the salad it's gonna crumble even more okay so 
there's that and then it's okay if you want to

break it up into short pieces like this mmm I 
love corn okay and then some cucumber julienned

like this um the way I cut it just to show you 
is I get it to this point and I cut it in half

I then removed the seeds for no other reason then 
the fact that it's lost a more stable to cut this

way and then I just go and cut Julien's from 
the piece of cucumber okay so I've got that and

then tomatoes briefly talk about it I'm using 
one roma tomato but if it cut straight on wet

just like this I find it's a little too big for a 
salad so what I like to do is through bias wedges

which basically is like this and then you turn 
and then you turn and then you turn and then you

keep going and the wedges become an interesting 
shape and it's also a nice bite-sized piece it's

comfortable to eat last thing we're gonna prep 
before we start making is our secret ingredient

which is theoretically optional but I highly 
highly recommend it it is Kai Kim or salted

duck eggs it is going to be that creamy salty 
burst the same way crumbled feta cheese is in

Greek salad so if you love tart tangy cheese 
over your salad you're gonna love this one so

what you want to do with this is cut it in half 
straight through the shell it's been salted so the

shells are actually really fragile or brittle so 
I like to make a crack and then cut right through

make sure I get all these shells to one side then 
it was scoop out one egg I mean one half I love

salted egg with congee I love it with just plain 
rice I just love salted eggs and then I'm going

to cut this half into sort of chunks this is 
probably good okay so this is for tossing into

our salad put that there this half I'm gonna try 
to get it out as nicely as I can so that I can

cut out wedges and put it on top of the salad now 
it's gonna be sort of creamy and soft so it's not

come if it's not coming out in one nice piece it's 
not a big deal I just like to have bigger pieces

so I can put them on top of the salad so leave 
that there alright so this is the fun part so

my tools for making any some thumb tight dish 
is my mortar and pestle now this is different

from the heavy duty stone one that I used in a 
lot of my other episodes this is a larger one

and also with a light wooden pestle and this 
is doesn't matter as much as this you want to

light wood and pestle because you just want to 
lightly crush you don't want to pound anything

into curry paste consistency so this is what 
I call the light duty one okay so we're gonna

first get started with our garlic we've got a 
couple cloves of garlic and some chilies take

off the top my rule of thumb is 1/4 mile to four 
medium and three or more for spicy okay and then

just pound this until there are no more chunks so 
once you've got that I'm gonna add my palm sugar

and I'm adding with a palm sugar early on because 
I'm using the hard type of palm sugar which is

gonna need a little bit of help dissolving and 
the sugar doesn't have to completely dissolve so

once you get it to sort of a wet paste like this 
that's good enough and then it'll be gone by the

time we're done with it so after that I'm gonna 
add my long beans and I just cut it into little

pieces like this on a bias so it's a little 
prettier also my dried shrimp now dry survive

using my papaya it's it's in pretty much every 
kind of some thumb type dish and it's just like

bursts of shrimpy chewiness a really nice boost 
in umami when you buy dried shrimp they come in

a lot of different sizes these are pretty small 
and I like to use small ones for papaya salad

so they distribute better if you've got large 
ones you don't need to go out and buy a small

one just give them a rough chop before you add 
them okay so there goes that and I'm just going

to crush it so that the beans are broken so 
they can absorb the dressing a little better

okay at this point we're gonna add all of our 
dressing ingredients so I'm gonna go in with

my fish sauce now lime I'm using a total of 
three tablespoons and that's about one juicy

North American size lime okay now with papaya 
salad I always like to choose the lime and then

throw in the rind into into the mortar so that 
the essential oils that limey flavor comes out

and gets distributed into the salad as well but 
this is a pretty big piece I'm just gonna cut it

real quick so I can throw it in there some of us 
are vendors don't even squeeze the lime they cut

the lime into very small slices throw them in and 
then just the act of pounding with juice all the

lime now we're gonna go in with also our tomatoes 
and now we're gonna be very gentle because we're

just gonna mix and we're gonna lightly crush the 
tomatoes just so that the juices of the tomatoes

come out and mix with everything and so they're 
a little bit bruised and they get a chance to

absorb all that dressing so here is what it looks 
like at this point okay a lot of dressing lots of

juiciness there the lime is in there infusing its 
flavor and the tomatoes are just mushed up and now

that the Jews is part of the dressing now is the 
moment we're waiting for is our main star goes in

our corn and our cucumber and that oh I think I 
added too much corn for this much I don't end up

using an entire corn and now we're just gonna toss 
I'm gonna throw this out well I'm gonna throw it

out I'm gonna retire it and I'm just gonna toss 
with my spoon breaking up the corn pieces so

they're smaller pieces but still in sort of you 
know attached chunks mmm smells so good already

awesome okay let me give it a taste real quick 
hmmm now for this remember that the corn itself

is already sweet so you don't want the dressing 
to be too sweet so the choice of vegetables that

you use will affect sort of the flavor balance 
of your dressing so that's something you want

to think about it's not the same dressing for 
everything and because I'm adding salted duck

eggs I'm not adding too much fish sauce so I'm 
tossing in my chunks of salted duck eggs by the

way something egg is a pretty common thing for us 
to have in our in our some thumb if you've ever

heard of some kite him that's what it means it's 
papaya salad with tight hem with the salted duck

eggs give it a quick toss and we're done we're 
ready to play it oh gosh I wish you could smell

this I can really smell the lime and by the way 
you could probably do this the line before you

juice it if you don't want to throw in if you 
think your guests are gonna be weirded out by

the big chunks of lime oh my god that looks so 
good I always want to readjust because I knew

all the salted eggs are gonna be buried and lost 
in there that's why I say it the other half of the

salted egg ever so gently placed them on top just 
so it's a visual representation of sort of what's

in there so people aren't surprised and there you 
go there's our thumb Banco poet now let me taste

it for you mmm oh yeah so refreshing you've 
got lightness crunchiness citrusy lime juice

it's so good so it's super easy and you 
don't have to use the vegetables that I

use so totally use your imagination and try it 
out with other things we use sometimes we use

apples once you use pummelo I mean there's 
just a million things we could do so when

you give it a try take a photo send it to me 
on Facebook Twitter or Instagram and share

with me your success stories and if you enjoy 
the show please click to subscribe so I could

keep doing what I'm doing and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious tiny
